did.head: Overview
did.unittitle: Leland Stanford papers

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

custodhist.p: Gifts of Jane Lathrop Stanford, Thomas Welton Stanford, David Starr Jordan, Helen Stanford Canfield, David H. Canfield, and others; also includes purchases.

accessrestrict.head: Information about Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Ownership & Copyright
userestrict.p: The materials are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use.

prefercite.head: Cite As
prefercite.p: [Identification of item] Leland Stanford Papers (SC0033A). Department of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHY
bioghist.p: Leland Stanford was born March 9, 1824 in Watervliet Township, New York. He was admitted to the practice of law in 1848 and married Jane Lathrop in 1850. In 1852, Stanford moved to California where he first worked as a storekeeper in Mother Lode mining camps and later became a successful Sacramento businessman. Stanford was a leader in organizing the Republican party in California and was elected governor in 1861 at the age of 37. Early in the 1860s, Stanford joined with three other Sacramento merchants--Charles Crocker, Mark Hopkins, and Collis P. Huntington--in the building of the Central Pacific Railroad. In 1885, Leland and Jane founded Leland Stanford Jr. University in memory of their son. Stanford died June 21, 1893 during his second term as United States Senator.

scopecontent.head: SCOPE AND CONTENT
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, telegrams; business, legal, financial, and official papers; speeches, journals, and newsclippings; and other materials relating to the construction of the Central Pacific Railroad, Stanford's political career, business and financial interests, and the founding and construction of Stanford University.

did.unittitle: University matters
LSJU letterpress book: outgoing letters signed mostly by H. C. Nash, Of note:
1891, May 11: Nash to Jordan re houses available for professors
1891, June 22: re contracting bids on cottages and plans for girls' dormitory
1891, July 14: Nash to Jenkins re O.L. Elliott wishes to occupy Cedro Cottage temporarily
1891, July 16: Nash to Mrs. Boye re Jewett Collection
1891, Oct. 30: Stanford to Shepley, Rutan & Coolidge re hiring Mr. Austin, beginning of school
1891, Nov. 9: Stanford to Olmsted "improving the grounds in accordance with your plans"

did.unittitle: thinks 15 professors enough to open with
decided to name boys dormitory Encina Hall
approves prospectus; names dormitories for oak trees
will have accommodations for 80 girls
thinks 4-5 thousand dollars sufficient to start library
do not engage Nissen
defer agricultural branch
no suggestions for circular no. 4

did.unittitle: recommends Dr. Charles of Menlo Park
Dr. Grau and Miss Ames on payroll; mistress of Roble Hall; pleased with address
must exercise own judgment on engaging profs. White, Dudley, Jenks and Angell
payment of professors for outside lectures; steam heat for gymnasium; getting President White as lecturer; finding meteors
suspend arrangements for heating gymnasium
introduces Mr. & Mrs. Morris K. Jessup
will be in Palo Alto in April
remuneration for Pres. White
faculty appointments [signature cut out]
case of Miss Hay

$5 a week sufficient for board
to hasten construction of buildings; too many professors and assistants
sends address in Paris
(tel): approval of lease form
issue of students' board
introduces Wilson Evans
Prof. Gale out of place in mechanical engineering; pleased with letter from Pres. White
students' expenses must not exceed $5 per week

dao.title: Outgoing correspondence to Jordan, D. S.,

did.unittitle: approval of appointment of Dr. Murray
experiments vs lectures; belief in immortality of the soul essential to civilization; golden rule foundation of true humanitarianism
students to pay only actual cost of living; our university to be of high grade; more dormitory space for girls is needed
does not want pay for tuition; possibility of students boarding themselves
sailing on the Majestic; visit from Pres. White
suggests ex-sen. Edmunds as commencement speaker
employees may go cheerfully if they can better themselves; teach only the fundamental principles of law; President Harrison and arbitration
regrets Prof. Swain leaving, willing to offer him position of Vice-President or Assistant to the Pres.
